awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Strengthening the Undergraduate STEM Curriculum at Fisk University through the Infusion of Computational-Biological content in Pre-Calculus
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Fisk University seeks to improve the undergraduate STEM curriculum and help the University achieve its aspiration of developing a Bioinformatics/Biomathematics or Quantitative and Computational Biology (QCB) major. The project's proposed curriculum innovation activities will serve as a testing ground for exploring the impact of teaching on student learning, retention in quantitative biology/mathematics/or computer science as majors, and selection of career pathways. This project will help to strengthen the research and learning culture and infrastructure at the University as it moves towards expanding into degree-granting biomathematics and bioinformatics programs. The project's activities are expected to increase interest in STEM fields, increase retention and progression in STEM disciplines, and will serve as a possible replicable model for other institutions that share a similar mission.

The overall goal of the program is to enhance and strengthen the existing undergraduate curriculum for STEM majors by introducing computational and data-enabled active learning in mathematics, biology and computer science, integrated with a faculty-mentored summer research program. To achieve this goal, the following activities are proposed: develop and implement a bio-pre-calculus course in order to provide biology students a better understanding of the applications of algebraic and trigonometric fundamentals in biological problems; offer short (one credit) courses to teach programming languages--Python, R, Linux, and Galaxy--often used for biological data processing and data analysis; offer a summer research program to a selected pool of 6 rising sophomores, juniors or seniors with biology, mathematics or computer science major, to develop competence in research; and offer computational and bio-mathematical research seminars and colloquia featuring speakers from departments and programs across campus, plus invited guests from industry and other universities to emphasize the use of computing to solve complex biological problems and develop new insight. This combination of activities will provide a solid interdisciplinary link between mathematics, computer science and biology; foster quantitative and discovery based learning on the topics of life sciences; stimulate students' research interests by enhancing their programming skill; and increase student participation in classrooms through data-enabled- and case-study-oriented active learning.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this Targeted Infusion Project was to enhance and strengthen the existing undergraduate curriculum for STEM majors with the recently initiated Quantitative Bio-track program at Fisk University, by introducing computational and data-enabled active learning in mathematics, biology, and computer science, integrated with a faculty-mentored summer research program. To achieve the goal, we completed the following activities: 1) developed and implemented a bio-pre-calculus course in order to provide biology students a better understanding of the applications of algebraic and trigonometric fundamentals in biological problems, 2) offered short (one credit) courses to teach the usage of programming languages-Python, R, Linux, and Galaxy, often used for biological data processing and data analyzing, 3) organized a summer research program to a selected pool of 6 undergraduate rising sophomores, juniors or seniors with biology, mathematics or computer science major, to enhance their research skill and to develop competence on working with research projects,  and  4) hosted computational and bio-mathematical research seminars and colloquia featuring speakers from departments and programs across campus, plus invited guests from industry and other universities to emphasize the use of computing in solving complex biological problems and developing new insight into the application of modern technology.

 

Intellectual Merit: This project strengthened the first step Fisk University has taken towards expanding into future degree-granting biomathematics and bioinformatics programs. The programming language courses developed through the project have helped students to gain confidence in utilizing them for doing their research work and completing their computational class assignments. In addition, these courses played an important role in preparing Fisk students for technology-oriented job market. The Precalculus for Life Sciences course helped to prepare students well for succeeding in their next required course, Bio-calculus, by teaching them some essential topics usually not covered in traditional precalculus courses. but encountered regularly in life science problems and pursuing related scientific research.  

 

The Summer Research Internship program has turned out to be very successful as the students found it highly beneficial for building their career.  It gave students the chance to focus on a research topic without being interrupted by financial or class obligations and under the direct guidance of a faculty mentor. The program was offered to a cohort of six UG students during summer of each project year for eight weeks with informal weekly presentations followed by a final written paper and an oral presentation.  The presentations helped students to build confidence and develop skills, both orally and in written form.  Summer research projects highlighted the interdisciplinary link between mathematics, computer science and biology, fostered quantitative and discovery-based learning on the topics of life sciences, stimulated students' research interests by enhancing their programming skills, and increased student participation in classrooms through data-enabled and case-study oriented active learning.

 

To motivate the students, the project also offered some biomathematics and bioinformatics related research seminars and guest colloquia emphasizing the use of computing and solving complex biological problems with mathematical details. These activities also served as a testing ground for exploring the impact of computational, mathematical, and biological courses on student learning, retention in related subject majors, and selection of career pathways. 

 

Broader Impact: This targeted infusion project established a strong interdisciplinary research base at Fisk University by enhancing the technology skill of Fisk students and faculty. It has brought interest and excitement for quantitative research in biological sciences. At Fisk University, an HBCU, with more than 98% students of color, and more than 90% students African American, our project had a direct impact on this population of increasing awareness and skills related to this rapidly expanding career opportunity. The activities initiated through the project increased student-interest in STEM related fields, increased retention, and progression in STEM disciplines, and is serving as possible replicable model for other institutions sharing similar mission. In addition, several students who have been through this project, are now continuing into graduate school with focus in bio-mathematical and/or computational topics. A couple of students are currently pursuing their PhDs, one in Epidemiology at Brown University and other in Bioinformatics at UCLA. Some students obtained jobs in STEM related fields.

 


Last Modified: 11/06/2021
Modified by: Sanjukta Hota

    Sample- Research project poster 2020
  • Project Title: Using Machine Learning to Diagnose Diabetes Mellitus of Pima Indians.By Zahra Rasuli (Data Science Sr), Valencia Heard(Biology Jr)
    NSF-TIP project 1719450
    Copyrighted
    Sanjukta Hota
    Sample- Research project poster 2019
  • Project Title: Quantitative Analysis of Dopamine-related Genes in C.elegansBy: Vivian Iloabuchi (Biology Jr),Ashley Cosby(Biology Jr)
    NSF-TIP project 1719450
    Copyrighted
    Sanjukta Hota
    Sample- Research project poster 2019
